title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include provisions for disclosure or identification of surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority by the Inspector General of an agency or other agency employee. The Inspector General or designated agency employee must report any surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the agency's Chief Financial Officer for review and potential rescission. If deemed feasible by the CFO, the agency head will transfer the identified funds from the appropriate appropriations account. The agency head can transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the general fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction or debt reduction. Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 does not apply to these transfers. The agency head can retain up to 10 percent of the transferred amounts. The agency head can transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the general fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction or debt reduction. The head of each agency must report annually to the Director of the Office of Personnel Management on employee disclosures of fraud, waste, or mismanagement, as well as savings achieved through these disclosures. The head of each agency must report identifications and cash awards in budget requests to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must submit an annual report to Congress and the Government Accountability Office on Federal cost savings and awards. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management ensures agency cash award programs comply with the law and reports to Congress annually. The Comptroller General submits a report to Congress every 3 years on the operation of the cost savings and awards program. The Comptroller General submits a report to Congress every 3 years on the operation of the cost savings and awards program, including recommendations for legislative changes. Officers at level I of the Executive branch are prohibited from receiving cash awards under this subchapter. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for receiving cash awards under a cost savings and awards program, specifying that individuals at level I of the Executive branch, agency heads, and voting members of independent establishments are eligible. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the table of sections in the United States Code. Prohibition of cash award to certain officers.
